2. Materials and approaches
2.1. Study sites and sampling
Four large alpine lakes in France (Lakes Aiguebelette, Annecy, Bourget and Geneva) were sampled during 2021 (see Table 1 for their main limnological characteristics). In total, 55 samples were collected seasonally during this year, i.e., 7 in Lake Aiguebelette, 14 in Lake Annecy, 16 in Lake Bourget and 18 in Lake Geneva. They were collected in the first 20 m using an integrated water sampler (IWS Hydro-bios©). Each sample was divided into 2 subsamples, one was used for microscopic identification and counting (100 mL), and the second (250 mL) was used for molecular analysis (see Supplementary, Table S1 for sampling dates). In the end, 55 samples were analyzed per method.  

2.2. Morphological analyses
The water subsamples (100 mL), intended for the taxonomic identification and counting of phytoplankton, were preserved with Lugol and stored in a dark, cool place until analysis. The Utermöhl technique (Utermöhl, 1958), standardized at European level (CEN, 2006), was used to prepare phytoplankton samples for microscopic analysis. Briefly, after decanting 25 mL of water in a microscopic chamber, algae counts and determinations were carried out under an inverted microscope (Zeiss Observer D1) at ×640 magnification using specialist literature (e.g., the various volumes of the Süsswasserflora von Mitteleuropa edited by B. Büdel, G. Gärtner, L. Krienitz and M. Schagerl). A minimum of 400 algal objects were counted following an ocular field transect. In such alpine lakes, to reach 400 objects, 40 to 100 fields are usually examined. The results were expressed in biovolume per volume of water (mm3.L−1) following the specific biovolumes used in Rimet and Druart (2018). To be comparable with molecular data (see Section 2.4), biovolumes of taxa per sample (species and genus biovolumes) were transformed into relative biovolumes per sample.

2.3. Molecular analyses
The water subsamples (250 mL), dedicated to the molecular analysis, were filtered in the laboratory on open filters with a porosity of 0.45 μm (MF-Millipore®, cellulose nitrate membrane filter). After filtration, each filter was cut into several pieces using sterile utensils to facilitate further DNA extraction, and then all the pieces were placed in a 2 mL Eppendorf tube and stored at −20 °C until the extraction process. DNA was extracted using the NucleoSpin soil kit (Macherey-Nagel), following the recommendations of the manufacturer. For the PCR amplification, the two genetic markers targeted were: the region V3 – V4 of the 16S rRNA (a barcode of 425 bp) using the pair of primers CYA359F (5′-GGGGAATYTTCCGCAATGG-3′) and CYA781Rd (5′-GACTACWGGGGTATCTAATCCCWTT-3′) (Nübel et al., 1997), and the UPA region of the 23S rRNA gene (a barcode of 402 bp) using the pair of primers ECLA23S_F1 (5′-ACAGWAAGACCCTATGAAGCTT-3′) ECLA23S_R1 (5′-CCTGTTATCCCTAGAGTAACTT-3′) (Canino et al., 2023). The new pair of primers, ECLA23S_F1/ECLA23S_R1, was designed and tested in silico and with mock communities (Canino et al., 2023). Briefly, five different pairs of primers for 23S rRNA were tested in the study of Canino et al. (2023) with in silico PCR and the Phytool barcode reference library. Two were newly designed primers and three came from the literature and included those of Sherwood and Presting (2007), and Yoon et al. (2016). Among these five pairs, three were selected. These three pairs (including the two pairs of newly designed primers) were then tested with two mock communities: one with DNA extracts from cultures of 10 different microalgae species, and the other with DNA amplicons from cultures of 18 different microalgae species. These two mock communities covered a wide range of phytoplankton classes (Cyanophyceae, Zygophyceae, Chlorophyceae, Trebouxiophyceae, Bacillariophyceae, Mediophyceae, Cryptophyceae, Eustigmatophyceae, Xanthophyceae). The ECLA23S_F1/ECLA23S_R1 primers gave the best results in terms of specificity and precision, and better respected the proportions of species DNA introduced in mock communities. These primers target the 23S UPA variable region (344 to 360 bp without primers) and can amplify cyanobacteria as well as eukaryotic species. Prior to PCR amplification, DNA was quantified using a NanoDrop (NanoDrop ONE ThermoScientific OZYME) and DNA concentrations ranged from 0.6 to 135.4 ng.L−1. Subsequent dilutions were made (if necessary) to adjust DNA concentration (to 5 ng.μL−1) between the different samples. For each genetic marker, the PCR amplification was performed using a total reaction volume of 25 μL containing 5 μL of each primer (forward and reverse; 1 μM), 12.5 μL of 2× KAPA HiFi HotStart Ready Mix (Roche Molecular Systems, Inc), and 2.5 μL of DNA template (5 ng.μL−1). Thermal cycling conditions consisted of an initial denaturation step of the DNA template and HotStart DNA Polymerase activation at 95 °C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles of 0.5 min at 95 °C, 0.5 min at 58 °C and 0.5 min at 72 °C and a final extension step of 5 min at 72 °C. Finally, the PCR products were sent for sequencing to the PGTB platform (Plateforme de Génomique et Transcriptomique, Bordeaux, France), using MiSeq technology (Illumina, SY-410-1003) and the v3 reagent kit (2
250 bp). One sequencing run was performed by genetic marker. The average expected number of reads per sample and the total expected number were equal to 50,000 reads 22 
 106 pairs of reads respectively, before the application of the bioinformatics pipeline.

2.4. Bioinformatics analysis
Sequence data were processed using a pipeline combining Cutadapt v3.5 (Martin, 2011) to remove primers and DADA2 (Callahan et al., 2016) to generate tables of amplicon sequence variants (ASV). This analysis pipeline is available at https://github.com/Github-Carrtel/2023_Nicolosi-Gelis_et_al. The paired-end fastq files obtained during sequencing were demultiplexed by the sequencing platform. The portions of sequence corresponding to primers CYA359F/CYA781Rd and ECLA23S_F1/ECLA23S_R1 were cut using Cutadapt v3.5 (Martin, 2011). For each genetic marker, forward and reverse reads were then trimmed at positions 220 and 220 respectively and reads with ambiguous nucleotides or with a maximum expected errors number (MaxEE) >2 were filtered out using the filterAndTrim() function from the R-package dada2 (Callahan et al., 2016). For each sequencing run, error rates were set using the learnErrors() function, reads were dereplicated using the derepFastq() function and denoised using the dada() function with the default options before being merged. The forward (R1) and reverse (R2) reads were then merged using the mergePairs() function and its default parameters. In order to be more rigorous on the selected reads, the merged sequences were filtered to keep only those with an average overlap length as expected (i.e., according to the given barcode length) at more or less 5 bp. Finally, the remaining chimeras were removed using removeBimeraDenovo() function. Taxonomic assignment was performed using the naive Bayesian classifier implemented in the R-package dada2 (assignTaxonomy() function), with a minimum bootstrap value of 75 % and the Phytool barcode reference library. This reference library includes taxonomic classifications of prokaryotes and eukaryotes for 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA.

For molecular data, prior to analysis, read counts were converted to relative abundances of reads per ASV for each sample and only those with a total relative abundance of reads >1 % were kept. From these raw data, two tables were constructed, i) a table of taxonomy-free ASV and ii) a table of taxonomically assigned ASV. To construct the latter table, all the ASVs assigned to the same species (or genus) were grouped together.

2.5. Data analysis
2.5.1. Gap analysis of Phytool barcode reference library
Two gap analyses were carried out between the floristic data from the microscopy and those from the Phytool barcode reference library for the two genetic markers (16S and 23S rRNA). Phytool is a barcode reference library dedicated to algae (including cyanobacteria). This library, as described in Canino et al. (2021), includes 30,575 algal and cyanobacterial sequences (16,654 sequences for 18S rRNA, 8479 for 16S rRNA, 1996 for 23S rRNA; 3446 for rbcL). The sequences were collected from different databases (Diat.barcode: Rimet et al., 2019; μgreen-db: Djemiel et al., 2020; GenBank: Benson et al., 2013; PhytoREF: Decelle et al., 2015; PR2: Guillou et al., 2013; SILVA: Quast et al., 2013) and an essential step was taken to homogenize their taxonomy. To correctly decipher natural communities, it is important that barcode reference libraries are as complete as possible. The first gap analysis was carried out to obtain a complete assessment of the taxonomic coverage of genera and species identified by microscopy in the reference libraries for 16S and 23S rRNA. The second was carried out to find out how many taxa recorded by microscopy and molecular approaches contribute to the calculation of the specific composition metric (MCS) of the phytoplankton index for lakes (IPLAC index; Laplace-Treyture and Feret, 2016).

2.5.2. Comparison of taxa detected by the different types of approaches
Across the 55 environmental samples, the numbers of taxa identified with the different approaches (i.e., microscopy, 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA) were compared by drawing Venn diagrams using the interactive tool Venny v.2.1 (Oliveros, 2007). This comparison was carried out at different taxonomic levels (i.e., Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus and Species). A comparative table of the dominant taxa (species level or lowest taxonomy level) detected using the two approaches was created. In addition, the species shared between the three approaches were identified and Spearman's correlation (with the R software and using the R-package stats) was used to check whether their relative abundances were correlated between the different methods.

2.5.3. Comparison of the diversity metrics between approaches
Richness, Pielou's evenness and Shannon diversity index were calculated for microscopic and molecular data using the R-package vegan (Oksanen et al., 2019). To test whether the values of each metric changed significantly between approaches, a Kruskal-Wallis test followed by a post-hoc test (Dunn test) were used. In addition, Spearman's correlation tests were used to assess whether metrics were correlated between microscopy and molecular approaches.

2.5.4. Comparison of phytoplankton communities detected with the different approaches
The congruence between phytoplankton communities derived from both microscopy and molecular approaches was assessed in a multivariate way using a co-inertia analysis, based on two normalized PCAs (using relative abundance), performed with the coinertia() function of the R-package ade4 (Dray and Dufour, 2007). This method aims to find orthogonal vectors (i.e., co-inertia axes) maximizing the sum of square covariances between two datasets (Doledec and Chessel, 1994). The congruence is estimated by calculating the multivariate correlation between the two data sets using the RV coefficient, a multivariate extension of the Pearson's coefficient (Escoufier, 1973). The significance of the association was tested using the Monte-Carlo test by comparing the observed RV coefficient to an expected distribution obtained by 9999 permutations. Co-inertia analyses were performed to estimate the co-structure between: i) microscopy and taxonomy-free data and ii) microscopy and taxonomically assigned ASVs' data. At the scale of each sampling date, the similarity between microscopy and molecular data (taxonomy-free or taxonomically assigned) was estimated by calculating the Euclidean distance between their scores in the factorial plan of each co-inertia analysis. This Euclidean distance is comparable to the length of an arrow in the factorial plan of the co-inertia analysis. A short arrow (i.e., a short Euclidean distance) indicates high congruence between the two data sets, while a long arrow (i.e., a strong Euclidean distance) indicates low congruence.

A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Kruskal-Wallis test was performed, depending on whether or not the normalization was satisfied according to a Kolmogorov-Smirnov's test (ks.test() function of the R-package stats). This analysis was used to test whether there was a significant difference in the Euclidean distances between microscopy data and the molecular data (16S or 23S rRNA), for both taxonomy-free and taxonomically assigned ASV.

2.5.5. Comparison of lakes trophic assessment obtained with morphological and molecular approaches using the MCS metric
The performances of microscopy and molecular approaches to assess the trophic level (in relation to nutrient concentration) of lakes was compared using the specific composition metric (MCS) of the Phytoplankton Index for Lakes (IPLAC; Laplace-Treyture and Feret, 2016). The IPLAC is an index used routinely to assess ecological status of French lakes under the WFD. The MCS metric is calculated using the Zelinka and Marvan formula (Zelinka and Marvan, 1961):
where 
 is the biovolume of species 
 in mm3L−1, 
 is the specific score of species 
, ranging from 0 to 20, and 
 is the stenoecy coefficient of species 
, ranging from 0 to 3. The specific score represents the optimum and the stenoecy coefficient represents the tolerance of the species in a gradient of total phosphorus. In order to be able to compare MCS metric values obtained by microscopy and metabarcoding, relative abundances were used. The values of the specific score and the stenoecy coefficient for each species were obtained from Laplace-Treyture and Feret (2016). The MCS values calculated with microscopy data were compared to those obtained with molecular data using a non-parametric Mann Whitney U test. A Spearman correlation between microscopy and molecular MCS values was also calculated to assess the relationship between the two approaches.

To estimate whether the MCS values, obtained with the two approaches, differed between lakes a one-way ANOVA was used. For each lake, a Spearman correlation test was also used to estimate the relationship between the MCS values obtained with the two approaches.

2 MATERIALS AND METHODS
2.1 Study sites and sampling
A total of 711 unique river sites were sampled to collect benthic diatoms. Sampling covered seven geographic regions from four continents (Africa, Europe, Oceania, and South America). They are located in the subpolar (Fennoscandia), temperate (France Mainland), and tropical (West Africa, French Guiana, New Caledonia, Tahiti island, and Mayotte island) climate zones, with latitude ranging from 68°N to 22°S. Geographic regions comprise four mainland zones (Fennoscandia, France Mainland, West Africa, and French Guiana) and three tropical islands (New Caledonia, Tahiti, and Mayotte). The sites are routinely sampled in the framework of local monitoring networks. The location of these sites was decided by the monitoring agencies to be representative of the ecological quality of each region; however, there is no background environmental data available for the samples obtained in the frame of this project. Further details on each dataset are available in Table 1 and Table S1 in Supporting Information. Diatoms were sampled during stable water seasons. At each site, biofilm was collected from at least five different stones by brushing their upper surfaces using a toothbrush (CEN, 2014). Samples were preserved in ethanol (70%) until sequencing (CEN, 2018). Samples (ethanol, biofilm, and DNA extracts) are vouchered at UMR CARRTEL (Thonon-les-Bains, France).

TABLE 1. Details for each sampled geographic region.
Region        Land type        Climate zone        Region size (km2)        Number of sites        Sampling years
Fennoscandia        Continent        Subpolar        1,173,926        26        2011–2015, 2019
France Mainland        Continent        Temperate        551,695        411        2016–2017
West Africa        Continent        Tropical        568,320        16        2019
French Guiana        Continent        Tropical        83,534        85        2013–2017
New Caledonia        Island        Tropical        18,576        64        2016
Tahiti        Island        Tropical        1044        15        2018
Mayotte        Island        Tropical        374        19        2014–2015
2.2 DNA extraction, amplification and sequencing
Pellets of biofilms were prepared by centrifuging (17,949 g for 30 min) between 2 and 4 mL of the initial biofilm suspension. Total genomic DNA was isolated from the pellets using the NucleoSpin® Soil kit (Macherey-Nagel) following the manufacturer's instructions.

A 312 bp fragment of the rbcL plastid gene was amplified using Takara LA Taq® polymerase and an equimolar mix of the forward primers Diat_rbcL_708F_1, 708F_2, 708F_3, and the reverse primers R3_1, R3_2, as described in Vasselon et al. (2017). A unique combination of forward and reverse adapters was included at the 5′-extremities of the forward and reverse primers to enable the multiplexing of all PCR products in a sequencing library. PCR reactions for each DNA sample were performed in triplicate using 1 μL of the extracted DNA in a final volume of 25 μL following the procedure described in Vasselon et al. (2017).

Equimolar concentrations of PCR products were pooled for each sample and sent to the sequencing platform where PCR amplicons were purified and libraries were prepared and quantified as described by Bailet et al. (2020). Sequencing was performed on an Illumina MiSeq platform using paired-end sequencing for 500 cycles with Standard kit v2. Samples were sequenced in six separate runs.

2.3 Bioinformatics
Bioinformatics data processing was performed as described by Tapolczai et al. (2019) using the software package DADA2 and following the methods described by Callahan et al. (2016). For further details, see Supplementary methods. Taxonomic assignment was performed using Diat.barcode version 9 (Rimet et al., 2019) with a bootstrap confidence threshold of 60% and the Naïve Bayesian Classifier algorithm (Wang et al., 2007).

Taxonomic filtering was applied to remove ASVs assigned to groups different from Bacillariophyta (diatoms) and ASVs containing less than 10 reads across all samples were excluded from further analyses. To compare samples without statistical bias, sample size was normalized to 18,000 reads (the lowest read number per sample) after verification that rarefaction curves exhibited saturation (Figure S1). Remaining high-quality rbcL rRNA gene sequences represented a total of 6548 unique ASVs.

2.4 Data analysis
Quantitative (relative abundances) and qualitative (presence-absence) sample-by-sequence ASVs tables were used to analyze diatom communities. Unless stated otherwise, statistical analyses were performed with R software 3.6.3 (R Core Team, 2017) and graphical representations with the ggplot2 package (Wickham, 2016).

Genetic alpha diversity was determined by calculating richness (number of ASVs based on presence-absence data) and diversity (Shannon index based on relative abundance data). Statistical differences were tested between climate zones (subpolar, temperate, or tropical) and land types (mainland or island) using Wilcoxon signed-rank test with Benjamini & Hochberg correction for multiple comparisons (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995). Generalized estimating equation models using Poisson distribution (Liang & Zeger, 1986) were applied using the geepack R package (Højsgaard et al., 2006) to test differences in the number of ASVs in function of latitude while allowing a correlation structure within regions (exchangeable matrix). The effect of land type (mainland or island) was also tested.

Nonmetric multidimensional scaling analysis (NMDS) on Bray–Curtis dissimilarity matrix (relative abundance data) was used to derive a two-dimensional configuration of ASVs community structures. Differences between geographic regions were tested with PERMANOVA with 999 permutations (Anderson, 2001). Shannon diversity and multivariate analyses were calculated with the package vegan (Oksanen et al., 2007).

The percentage of exclusive and shared ASVs (presence-absence data) was calculated for geographic regions, land types, climate zones, and continents. To control for differences related to the sampling effort, mean of shared and unique ASVs was calculated 1000 times after randomized subsampling to the lowest sample number (15 for regions, 26 for climate zones, and 35 for continents). Percentages of exclusive and shared ASVs were shown in barplots representing the size of different sets (Lex et al., 2014). The number of exclusive and shared ASVs was presented in a global map to visualize the distribution patterns of genetic variants.

To study the effect of genetic resolution on the proportion of exclusive and shared variants between regions, the computations described above were performed on clustered operational taxonomic units (OTUs) and species. To obtain OTUs, ASVs were clustered with the farthest neighbor clustering method and similarity threshold from 99% to 80% using the R package bioseq (Keck, 2020).

2. Materials and methods
2.1. Study site
The study area is within the Duero River basin in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula, which is in south-western Europe. It has an area of 97,000 km2, of which 81% is in Spain and 19% is in Portugal. Samples were taken from ponds (Fig. 1; Supplementary Material 1) located between 600 and 1200 m above sea level (m asl) in Spain. Agricultural intensification, rainfed crops which have shifted classification to irrigated crops in recent decades, was suspected to have major impacts on these lakes. The selected lakes cover a wide range of environmental conditions (Table 1).

2.2. Sampling
In total, 77 ponds were sampled during Spring of the period from 2018 to 2021. Diatoms were dislodged from the submerged stems of Schoenoplectus lacustris (L.) Palla, or Typha domingensis (Pers.) Steud, when S. lacustris was absent. In accordance with suggestions from previous studies (Blanco and Bécares, 2006, Blanco et al., 2004), at least 10–12 stems were randomly selected over the pond surface and cut at 10 cm below the water level in each pond. For each pond, the stems were placed together in a 1 L plastic bottle filled to 0.5 L with distilled water. Then, the bottles were shaken for two minutes to detach the diatoms from the stems (Zimba and Hopson, 1997, Riato et al., 2018, Borrego-Ramos et al., 2019). A subsample for microscopy analysis was preserved in 4% v/v formaldehyde, and a subsample for molecular analysis was conserved in 70% v/v ethanol and stored in the dark for further analysis. At the same time, for each pond, a water sample was collected for diatom sampling in order to evaluate the nutrient level. Total nitrogen (mg L-1) and total phosphorus (µg L-1) concentrations were determined following standard procedures (Association, 1989).

2.3. Molecular analysis
Samples collected in 2018 (22 ponds) were treated following the protocol described in the works of Borrego-Ramos et al. (2021) and Nistal-García et al. (2021), summarizing the DNA which was extracted using the PowerSoil® DNA Isolation Kit (Mo Bio Laboratories, Carlsbad, CA, USA). For each DNA sample, six PCR replicates were carried out on 10–20 ng/μL of extracted DNA in a mixture (50 μL final volume) containing 2 U of Platinum™ II Taq Hot-Start DNA Polymerase (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY, USA), 10 μL of 5 × Platinum™ II PCR Buffer, 0.5 μM of each primer, 5 μL of dNTP mix (2 mM each), 10 μL of Platinum™ GC Enhancer, and 9.6 μL of nuclease-free water. PCR conditions included an initial denaturalization step at 94 °C for 4 min followed by 40 cycles of denaturalization at 94 °C for 30 s, annealing at 55 °C for 30 s and extension at 68 °C for 30 s, and a final extension step at 68 °C for 10 min. The libraries preparation and sequencing were carried out by Sistemas Genómicos S.L. (Valencia, Spain).

Samples collected in 2019, 2020, and 2021, were treated according to the following protocol. DNA was isolated from a 2 mL subsample centrifuged at 11,000 G for 30 min. The supernatant was discarded, and the pelleted material was resuspended in nuclease-free water. Extraction was performed using the PowerSoil® DNA Isolation Kit (Mo Bio Laboratories, Carlsbad, CA, USA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The gene marker rbcL was amplified by PCR using the primers proposed by Rivera et al. (2018) and Vasselon et al. (2017), an equimolar mix of three PCR primers, 3 forward (Diat_rbcL_708F_1 (AGGTGAAGTAAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA), Diat_rbcL_708F_2 (AGGTGAAGTTAAAGGTTCWTAYTTAAA) and Diat_rbcL_708F_3 (AGGTGAAACTAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA)), and two reverse (Diat_rbcL_R3_1 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACWACTG) and Diat_rbcL_R3_2 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACAACAG)), including Illumina adapters P5 (CTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT) and P7 (GGAGTTCAGACGTGTGCTCTTCCGATC). For each DNA sample, three PCR replicates were performed on 1 μL of extracted DNA in a mixture (25 µL final volume) containing 0.5 µL Phire® Hot Start II DNA Polymerase, 5 μL of Buffer 5X, 2 μL of dNTP mix (2 mM each), 0.25 μM of each primer, and 14.5 μL of nuclease-free water. PCR conditions included an initial denaturalization steps at 94 °C for 4 min followed by 40 cycles of denaturalization at 94 °C for 30 s, annealing at 55 °C for 30 s and extension at 68 °C for 30 s, and a final extension step at 68 °C for 10 min. After PCR, the amplification of the rbcL was evaluated using 1.5% agarose gel electrophoresis stained with ethidium bromide and visualized with UV light. DNA metabarcoding libraries and sequencing were carried out by AllGenetics & Biology SL (A Coruña, Spain).

PCRs2 was carried out in a final volume of 25 µL, containing 2.5 µL of DNA from the PCR products received, 1 µM of the dual-indexed primers, 6.5 µL of Supreme NZYTaq 2x Green Master Mix (NZYTech), and ultrapure water up to 25 µL. The reaction mixture was incubated as follows: an initial denaturation at 95 °C for 5 min, followed by 5 cycles of 95 °C for 30 s, 60 °C for 45 s, 72 °C for 45 s, and a final extension step at 72 °C for 7 min. A negative control that contained no DNA (BPCR) was included in every PCR round to check for contamination during library preparation. The libraries were run on a 2 % agarose gel stained with GreenSafe (NZYTech), and imaged under UV light to verify the library size. Libraries were purified using the Mag-Bind® RXNPure Plus magnetic beads (Omega Biotek), following the instructions provided by the manufacturer. Then, libraries were pooled in equimolar amounts according to the quantification data provided by the Qubit™ dsDNA HS Assay (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The pool was sequenced in a fraction of a MiSeq PE300 run (Illumina).

2.4. Bioinformatic analysis
Bioinformatic analyses were performed using DADA2 version 1.21 (Callahan et al., 2016, p. 2) following the workflow implemented in diat.barcode package version 0.0.0.9000 (Keck, 2020). Primers were removed with Cutadapt version 3.4 (Martin, 2011). The taxonomic assignment was conducted using the diat.barcode v9 reference database (Rimet et al., 2016; available at https://www6.inrae.fr/carrtel-collection/Barcoding-database/Database-download, accessed in March 2022), and alignment was carried out using Seaview5 (Gouy et al., 2021) and Muscle (Edgar, 2004).

All amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) with more than 10 reads, belonging to Phylum Bacillariophyta, and with a length of 263 bp were kept for the analyses (the others were discarded). In order to avoid the bias introduced by the different sequencing depth among samples, we performed rarefaction using the rrarefy function of the vegan v4.0.4 package (Oksanen et al., 2019) in R. Diatom species codes followed by those given in OMNIDIA software (Lecointe et al., 1993).

2.5. Statistical analyses
For the subsequent analysis, three genera with the greatest variability in genetic variants and the greatest number of assigned species of the ASVs were selected: Gomphomema, Nitzschia and Achnanthidium. The spatial variables that made it possible to determine the global spatial structure of the communities were obtained by means of a Principal Coordinates of Neighbor Matrix (PCNM) analysis (Borcard and Legendre, 2002, Borcard et al., 2004). This means that we used this approach to determine whether spatial characteristics had an effect on the heterogeneity of diatom communities in the pond, following the methodology used in previous studies (Rimet et al., 2019). This approach is based on each sampling site’s coordinates, determining the Euclidean distance between them. To explore the distribution on variance of the environmental and geographical variables, a variance partitioning was carried out using a forward selection method based on RDA models of each group of variables (chemical, physical, and geographical distances). Redundancy Analysis (RDA) with variance partitioning was used to examine the spatial structure of diatom pond communities. We conducted this analysis using the varpart function in the vegan package in R (Oksanen et al., 2019).

Mantel test and partial Mantel test (Legendre and Legendre, 2013) were carried out to explore the influence of environmental variables or geographical distance on the structure of diatom assemblages, examining the relationship between community dissimilarity matrix and abiotic factors.

Canonical Correspondence Analysis (CCA) was carried out with chemical variables and ASVs to explore the relationship between the environmental variables from the studied ponds and the sequences assigned at species level. All analyses were conducted with R (R Core Team, 2019) using the vegan package (Oksanen et al., 2019).

Phylogenetic trees were built based on the substitution model with lowest BIC (Bayesian Information Criterion) using MEGA-X (Tamura et al., 2007). First, we tested the phylogenetic signal at the species level, with the species that had the highest number of sequences. Then, we repeated the analyses with the sequences at the genus level. To do that, the three most abundant genera were selected, so only Amplicons Sequence Variation (ASVs) belonging to Achnanthidium, Nitzschia, and Gomphonema with more than 100 reads were used to calculate the phylogenetic signal. All ASVs present only in one sample were removed. To analyze the response of the sequences variability and the phylogeny of diatoms with respect to abiotic factors, we used Moran’s I (Moran, 1948) and Abouheif’s Cmean (Abouheif, 1999) indices to test the significance of the phylogenetic signal using the function phyloSignal in the phylosignal package in R (Keck et al., 2016b). Moran’s I index is the most commonly used autocorrelation measure in spatial statistics. Abouheif’s Cmean quantifies the autocorrelation between tips, from a specific matrix of phylogenetic proximities.

column2:
2.1 Study area and sampling sites
Two sampling sites were located at the shoreline of Lake Geneva (Thonon les Bains, France) as described in Rivera et al. (2021). Biofilm samples were collected at these two sites every 2 weeks over a year and a half period, from November 2018 to January 2020.

One site was located in a small harbor and the other one at a stony beach about 100 m from the harbor. Biofilms collected at the beach site (from now “beach biofilms”), consisted on natural biofilms collected directly on beach stones (Figure 1). The age of the biofilms may range from a few days to 1 month or more. Indeed, beach biofilms were regularly submitted to wave action resulting from prevailing northeast winds. Depending on the wind speed, waves can vary from few centimeters to 1 m when winds reach 30 km/h or more. In exceptional cases, winds between 70 and 80 km/h can occur which give rise to 2 m waves which completely strip biofilms from the stones.

Details are in the caption following the image
FIGURE 1
Open in figure viewer
PowerPoint
Location of the sampling sites and illustrations of the biofilms collected at the harbor and at the beach.
At the harbor site, no stones were available for biofilms development, thus biofilms collected in this site (from now “harbor biofilms”) developed on artificial substrates (Plexiglas plates) that were displayed for a controlled colonization period of 15 days (Figure 1). In contrast to beach biofilms, harbor biofilms were protected against wind events and wave action by a jetty.

2.1.1 Beach biofilms
Beach biofilm collection was conducted as described in Rivera et al. (2021). Briefly, at each sampling date, three biological replicates were collected (A, B, and C; Figure 1) along the shoreline of the stony beach. Biological replicates were separated by 1–1.5 m. For each replicate, five stones situated at 60–70 cm depth were collected randomly and placed in a clean basin in order to drain off the water from the lake, thus avoiding the collection of fish eDNA that may be present in the water. Then, a known surface of the biofilm of 187 cm2 was recovered by placing a plastic mold on the upper surface of each stone and scraping of the biofilm from the delimited area with a clean toothbrush and ultra-purified water (Milli-Q). Beach biological replicates were stored separately in sterile 50 mL Falcon tubes.

2.1.2 Harbor biofilms
Harbor biofilms were collected from nine Plexiglas plates of 215 cm2 each which were displayed on a 6 m long rope at 15 cm depth for biofilm colonization, 15 days prior to sample collection. At each sampling date, three biological replicates (A, B, and C) were performed (Figure 1). For each replicate, three Plexiglas plates were placed in a clean basin to drain off the water from the lake. Then, biofilm was recovered by scraping of both sides of the Plexiglas plates with a clean toothbrush and a clean scraper. Harbor biological replicates were stored separately in sterile 50 mL Falcon tubes.

Cross-contamination between biological replicates was avoided by using individual clean material for each sample. Furthermore, fields blanks were performed at each sampling site to check for DNA contamination as described in Rivera et al. (2021). Field blanks consisted on 50 mL sterile Falcon tubes previously filled with ultra-purified water (Milli-Q), carried into the field, and poured into a blank basin. Then, the surface of the basin was scraped with a clean toothbrush and the resulting water was recovered into the 50 mL Flacon tube.

After collection, biofilm samples and field blanks were returned to the laboratory in a cooler in less than 2 h, without any preservative added.

Beach biofilms were collected every 2 weeks from November 2018 to January 2020 (31 biofilms samples and 31 field blanks), while harbor biofilms were collected every 2 weeks from December 2018 to December 2020 (25 biofilms samples and 25 field blanks).

2.2 Biofilm characterization
Beach and harbor biofilm biomass was quantified as ash-free dry mass (AFDM). For this, 2 mL of each biofilm sample was filtered into a 47 mm pre-weighed GF/F glass microfiber filter (Whatman™). The filter containing the slurry was first dried at 105°C for 24 h and finally ignited at 500°C for 4 h (ash-free weight). AFDM was expressed in mg/cm2.

2.3 Total DNA extractions from biofilms
Immediately after sampling, biofilms samples were manually homogenized and a volume of 2 mL of each sample was used as starter for DNA extraction. Then 2 mL samples were first centrifuged at 8000g for 10 min at 4°C in a 2 mL Eppendorf© tube and the supernatant containing water was discarded. The remaining pellet was preserved at −20°C until DNA extraction. Total genomic DNA was extracted from the pellets using the Macherey-Nagel NucleoSpin® Soil kit (Macherey-Nagel, GmbH) with a final elution volume of 30 μL following the manufacturer instructions.

2.4 Fish DNA amplification from biofilms and sequencing
PCR amplification of fish communities was performed by targeting a short fragment (163–185 bp) of the mitochondrial 12S rRNA gene using the MiFish-U-F and MiFish-U-R primers (Miya et al., 2015). Forward and reverse primers were tagged respectively with half of the 5′-CTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT-3′ and half of the 5′-GGAGTTCAGACGTGTGCTCTTCCGATCT-3′ Illumina adapters in order to prepare Illumina libraries in a dual-step PCR approach. For the PCR1, each DNA sample was amplified in a final volume of 25 μL using the tailed Mifish-U primers and the AmpliTaq Gold DNA Polymerase following mix and reactions conditions used previously in Rivera et al. (2021). Three PCR replicates per sample were performed. Each PCR replicate was composed of three individual PCR which was subsequently pooled together. When PCR failed, extra individual PCR was performed to reach the required number of technical replicates. In some cases, amplification of the beach and the harbor biofilm samples was not reached (Table S1). Two negative controls were included in each PCR to check for potential contamination. Two mock communities of know composition were used as a PCR-positive control to monitor the performance of the amplification and the sequencing process. Mock community construction is described in Rivera et al. (2021) and its composition (from now “expected” mock community) can be found in Table S2.

After PCR1, PCR-negative controls and field blanks appeared negative, however, they were transferred to the GenoToul Genomics and Transcriptomics platform (GeT-PlaGe, Auzeville, France) along with all PCR replicates of each sample (beach and harbor biofilms and the mock communities). At the platform, a second PCR (PCR2) amplification was performed using the purified PCR1 amplicons as template and the Illumina-tailed primers to add dual-index specific to the samples. They furthermore prepared the final pool that corresponds to an equimolar mix of the 390 PCR2 dual-indexed amplicons and carried out the sequencing of the pool using Illumina MiSeq sequencing with V2 paired-end sequencing kit (2 × 150 bp). Sequencing was carried out in two different runs, each run contained a mock sample in triplicate to evaluate sequencing performance between the two runs. The composition of each mock community resulting from sequencing (from now “observed mock community”) is detailed in Table S2. Since field blanks and PCR-negative controls were confirmed negative during PCR2 they were not included in the sequencing process.

2.5 Bioinformatics
Sequence data processing of all samples (biofilm samples and mock communities) was performed using DADA2 v1.16.0 (Callahan et al., 2016) as implemented in R (R Core Team, 2020) and following the bioinformatics workflow described in Rivera et al. (2021) which was previously validated against a mock community. Briefly, primers were removed from the forward and the reverse reads using cutadapt 2.9 (Martin, 2011), then forward and reverse reads were quality filtered using the filterAndTrim function using default settings.

Forward and reverse sequences shorter than 120 nucleotides, containing ambiguous nucleotides and with more than two expected errors were removed. R1 and R2 reads were then dereplicated into individual unique sequences using the derepFastq function. Amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) were selected based on the error rate models determined by the DADA2 denoising algorithm and paired reads were merged into one sequence using the mergePairs function. Only paired reads presenting an identical overlap region of at least 30 bp were kept. Finally, chimeric ASVs were identified and removed using the removeBimeraDenovo function and the resulting ASV were taxonomically assigned in Mothur software v.1.44.3 (Schloss et al., 2009) using a local reference fish library (available at https://doi.org/10.15454/AU8EZI) and the naïve Bayesian classifier method (Wang et al., 2007) with a confidence score threshold of 75%. Local reference library construction and curation are detailed in Rivera et al. (2021). Only ASVs belonging to fish (Teleostei) were kept for further analysis (Table S3). The number of remaining reads after each bioinformatics step is detailed in Table S4.

After taxonomic assignment, further manual refining of the dataset was performed by completing taxonomic assignment of some taxa that could not be identified at species level and remained as “unclassified” (e.g., Coregonus “unclassified,” Silurus “unclassified,” Phoxinus “unclassified”). We were able to make these modifications because only one species of each of these different genera occurs at Lake Geneva, therefore avoiding any risk of misidentification. In addition, taxa from the same genus but assigned to difference species (e.g., Salvelinus fontinalis, S. alpinus, and S. namaycush) were combined into one single species (S. alpinus) given that there is a single Salvelinus in Lake Geneva.

Raw sequences of the mock community and the environmental samples are available at doi: 10.5281/zenodo.5864552.

Details of the manual refining are available in Table S5.

column2:
2. Material and methods
2.1. Sampling area and samplings
High altitude lakes above 1500 m altitude from two different geographical areas were sampled: in the French Alps, and in the Caucasian mountains of Georgia. The French Alps are situated on the far western end of the Alps, and cover an area of about 30,000 km2 which is composed of several mountain ranges. A total of 34 lakes were sampled during summer 2013, covering three main mountain ranges: Belledonne (6 lakes), the northern Alps (9 lakes), and the mid-southern Alps (19 lakes). The Georgian part of the Caucasian mountains covers two main mountain ranges. A total of 19 lakes were sampled during summer 2018: the Greater Caucasus mountain (5 lakes), and the Lesser Caucasus mountains (14 lakes). Surface areas of the lakes ranged from 1051 m2 to 36 km2. Fig. 1 shows the location of the lakes. Physico-chemical parameters were measured in the French lakes (Feret et al., 2017), and the conductivity ranged from 9 to 959 μs/cm (average 122 μS/cm), pH from 6.9 to 8.6 (average 7.9), NO3− ranged from 0.001 to 0.100 mgN/L (average 0.034 mgN/L), Total P from 0.001 to 0.043 mgP/L (average 0.010 mgP/L). Unfortunately physico-chemical were not measured in Georgian lakes. Geology surrounding lakes in France was in 59 % of the cases carbonate and in 41 % metamorphic. In all the cases it was carbonate in Georgia.

Fig. 1

Download : Download full-size image
Fig. 1. Location of the lakes sampled. (a) global location, (b) Lakes sampled in France and (c) in Georgia. For each lake, three littoral sites were sampled, except 8 lakes in France where 2 samples were taken.

The list of the sampled lakes, including their geographical coordinates, are given in Supplementary material S1.

Freshwater benthic diatoms were sampled according to the European guidelines for diatom metabarcoding sampling (CEN, 2014, CEN, 2018). For each lake, we collected three samples at three different sampling stations, except several lakes in France (8 lakes) where only two samples were taken. These sampling stations were chosen so that the distance between them was maximized. The geographical coordinates of each sampling station are given in Supplementary material S1. We ensured that all sampling stations were located in unshaded areas, away from effluent arrivals, peatlands, and mountain huts. For each sample, we collected five stones at 40–50 cm depth and we scrapped their upper surface using a clean toothbrush. We scraped a minimal surface of 100 cm2 for each sample. We fixed the biofilms with a minimal final concentration of 70 % ethanol before further treatment. All samples were further treated individually (no composite samples).

2.2. DNA extraction and sequencing
DNA extractions and PCR were carried out as described in Rivera et al. (2020). Specifically, the suspended diatom biofilm (2 ml) was centrifuged for 30 min at 13,000 rpm. A commercial DNA extraction kit Macheray-Nagel NucleoSpin® Soil kit (MN-Soil) was used following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quantity and quality were checked using a NanoDrop™ 1000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). We amplified a 312 bp barcode of chloroplastic DNA, embedded in the rbcL gene, which encodes for Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase. This barcode is recommended for diatom species identification (e.g., Kermarrec et al., 2013; Vasselon et al., 2017). We used the diatom specific primers Diat_rbcL_708F_1 (AGGTGAAGTAAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA), Diat_rbcL_708F_2 (AGGTGAAGTTAAAGGTTCWTAYTTAAA), and Diat_rbcL_708F_3 (AGGTGAAACTAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA) as forward primers, and Diat_rbcL_R3_1 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACWACTG) and Diat_rbcL_R3_2 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACAACAG) as reverse primers (Vasselon et al., 2017). Each DNA extract was amplified in triplicate using equimolar mixes of the three forward and two reverse primers. Half of the P5 (CTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT) and P7 (GGAGTTCAGACGTGTGCTCTTCCGATCT) Illumina adapters were included to the 5′ part of the rbcL forward and reverse primers, respectively. Additionally, blank samples using water of molecular quality were run in parallel to check for potential contaminations introduced during handling the samples in the lab. Amplifications were performed in a final volume of 25 μl following mix and reaction conditions used by Rivera et al. (2020), the number of amplification cycles was set to 33 and the conditions of a cycle were as follow: 95 °C – 1 min, 54 °C – 1 min, 72 °C – 1 min. For each sample, DNA of three replicates was extracted and amplified, after which they were pooled, and 50 μl was sent for sequencing at on an Illumina MiSeq platform at GetPlage Toulouse, France (https://get.genotoul.fr). The PCR amplicons were purified and used as templates in a second PCR that used Illumina tailed primers targeting the half of P5 and P7 sequences. Finally, all generated PCR amplicons were dual-indexed and pooled into a single tube. The final pool was sequenced using the V2 paired-end sequencing kit (250 bp × 2) for MiSeq platform.

2.3. Bioinformatic analysis
We used the DADA2 pipeline version 1.18.0 (Callahan et al., 2016) for the bioinformatics treatment of the demultiplexed MiSeq reads. We applied a custom pipeline adapted to diatom metabarcoding sequence data (available on https://github.com/fkeck/DADA2_diatoms_pipeline) (Tapolczai et al., 2021). Briefly, removal of primers from forward and reverse reads was carried out with cutadapt 2.9 (Martin, 2011). Quality profiles of forward and reverse reads were checked in DADA2: the pattern showed good read quality and only the last 20–30 bp decreased in quality score (Supplementary material S2).

Forward and reverse reads were filtered and truncated to remove poor quality sequences (truncLen = c(200, 170), maxN = 0, maxEE = c(2, 2), truncQ = 2). The estimated error rates fit well to the observed rates, and the error rates decrease with increased quality (Supplementary material S3). Subsequently, sequences were dereplicated, ASVs were inferred, and chimeras were removed. Read numbers in each sample were tracked after each bioinformatic step (Supplementary material S4). Taxonomic assignment of ASVs (Amplicon Sequence Variant) was carried out with the open-access Diat.barcode reference barcoding library (Rimet et al., 2019b) version 10 (https://www6.inrae.fr/carrtel-collection/Barcoding-database/). We used the R package “diat.barcode” (Keck, 2020), with a minimum bootstrap confidence of 60 (according to Rivera et al., 2020) for assigning a taxonomic level (Supplementary material S5). After taxonomic assignment, we carried out several data refinement steps to remove non-diatom sequences, as well as sequencing mistakes and sequences with spurious taxonomic assignments (see also Supplementary material S5). First, all ASVs not assigned to diatoms were removed. Second, ASV sequences were aligned in Seaview (Gouy et al., 2010) using the Muscle algorithm (Edgar, 2004), after which the alignments were manually checked. Since rbcL is a coding region, sequences which harbored insertions or deletions were removed. Then, sequences with more or <263 bp were removed, because the target length is 263 bp, and we translated sequences to amino-acids using MEGA10 (Kumar et al., 2018) to check for stop codons (none were found). Third, ASVs which presented ten or less reads in the entire database were removed to eliminate erratic ASVs. At last, data were rarefied in R using rrarefy function of Vegan (version 2.5.7) (Oksanen et al., 2013), based on the sample with the lowest number of reads in our dataset (sample DCOM3.1: 3915 reads). Two final tables were produced. The first table gives the communities at sub-species (i.e., haplotype) level including the number of reads per ASV for each sample. The second table gives the communities at species level including the number of reads per species (reads of ASVs belonging to the same species were summed) for each sample. All data (Fastq files, data tables) are available at doi:10.57745/A7HIWL

2.4. Data analysis
2.4.1. Species turnover
The Bray-Curtis distances between communities, calculated on the rarefied data, were visualized through violin plots at species and sub-species level using Past version 4.09 (Hammer et al., 2001). Using Dunn's post hoc tests in Past, we tested for significant differences in between-community Bray-Curtis distances at various geographical scales (countries, mountain range within country, and lakes).

In addition, to investigate community structure and visually assess species turn-over through different geographical scales, NMDS (Nonmetric Multidimensional Scaling) was calculated with Bray-Curtis distances using the metaMDS function of the Vegan package version 2.5-7 in R (Supplementary data S7). NMDS was calculated with both species and sub-species tables, and visualized using ggplot2 version 3.3.5 (Wickham, 2016) in R. To test whether communities considered at different geographical scales (country, mountain range, lake) harbored significantly different compositions, permutational multivariate analysis of variance using Bray-Curtis distance were calculated using Vegan's adonis2 function.

2.4.2. Endemism measured through Zeta diversity
Endemism is usually measured as the number of species confined to smaller patches within a larger area (Kinzig and Harte, 2000). Here, we used the multisite metric “zeta diversity” (Hui and McGeoch, 2014) to assess endemism. Zeta diversity describes the number of taxa shared across multiple sites: it expresses the number of endemics, using z-diversity as a function of the number of sites sampled rather than of area per se. When the number of sites tends to infinity, Zeta diversity assesses the number of globally endemic taxa.

Read numbers in the species and sub-species tables were transformed into presence/absence data to process Zeta diversity calculations. The zetadiv v 1.2.0 package (Latombe et al., 2018) in R was used. The zeta.ddecay function was used to measure the diversity decline along geographical distances. To this end, we fixed the Zeta diversity order to 3. This was done because 3 samples were taken in each lake (see Section 2.1), and this would therefore enable to assess the average number of shared taxa inside lakes. We used orthodromic distances to measure geographical distances between sites (distance.type = “ortho”). The Zeta.ddecay function was applied on the community tables (species and sub-species), and we set the number of bootstraps to 5000 (“sam = 5000”). However, we observed that the number of Zeta diversity indices calculated for samples belonging to the same lake was small. Therefore, we ran this function again for samples that originated from a single country (France, Georgia) to maximize the chances of comparing sites coming from the same lakes, using 1000 bootstraps (“sam = 1000”). Zeta diversity values were then represented through box-plots in Past at four geographical scales: <1 km (mostly comparing samples from the same lake), from 1 to 50 km (mostly samples from the same region/mountain range), 50 to 500 km (samples from the same country), and >500 km (comparing samples from France and Georgia).

2.4.3. Testing for a geographic signal in the phylogenies of the most abundant taxa
We tested if there was allopatric diversification for abundant and cosmopolitan species that harbor intraspecific diversity. To this end, we constructed phylogenies and haplotype networks for the most abundant and phylogenetically diverse species and used phylogenetic indices to test if geographical repartition was conserved over time (Keck et al., 2016). The following paragraphs are giving the methodological details.

We selected the five most abundant taxa in terms of read number that harbored six or more ASVs. For these taxa, we tested if intraspecific phylogenetic clades were restricted to geographical areas, namely Georgia or France.

In a first step, a haplotype network for each taxon was calculated to visually assess if geographical structure is present inside the data. To this end, we used the functions “haplotype” and “haploNet” available in the R-package pegas version 1.1 (Paradis, 2010).

In a second step, we tested whether ASVs that originated from the same country clustered together in a phylogenetic context. The following process was carried out for each species. To this end, ASVs were aligned using the Muscle algorithm in Seaview for each taxon separately. Using these alignments, we build a maximum likelihood (ML) phylogeny in RaxmlGUI (Silvestro and Michalak, 2012), with rapid bootstrap tests and a gamma GTR substitution model according to Modeltest results calculated in RaxmlGUI (Silvestro and Michalak, 2012). Then, we used the function “phyloSignal” from the R-package phylosignal version 1.3 (Keck et al., 2016) to calculate the different tests of phylogenetic signal, namely “I” (Gittleman and Kot, 1990), “Cmean” (Abouheif, 1999), “Lambda” (Pagel, 1999), “K”, and “K.star” (Blomberg et al., 2003). These indices use different strategies to test if the repartition of a trait (in our case, geographic distribution) in a phylogeny is significantly different from a random repartition. As input data of the “phyloSignal” analyses for each species, we used the ML phylogeny calculated with RaxmlGUI and the number of sites occupied in Georgia and in France.

2.4.4. Automated molecular species delimitation on Achnanthidium
In the previous section, we extracted ASVs belonging to the most common species in our dataset and assumed absence of hidden species level diversity when testing for a geographic signal in their phylogenies. However, diatoms are notorious for harboring (pseudo)cryptic species (e.g., Pinseel et al., 2020), many of which are little studied. To test whether the most abundant taxa in our dataset harbored potential for hidden species level diversity, we applied two methods for automated molecular species delimitation that have previously been successfully used to delimit (pseudo)cryptic taxa in diatoms (Kollár et al., 2019; Pinseel et al., 2020): Statistical Parsimony Network Analysis, SPNA (Templeton et al., 1992) and Automated Barcode Gap Discover, ABGD (Puillandre et al., 2012). These are both distance-based methods that use an alignment as input for estimating species boundaries.

Although the five most abundant taxa belong to five different genera (i.e., Achnanthidium, Cymbella, Denticula, Encyonema and Encyonopsis), we decided to focus this analysis on Achnanthidium only. This was done because substantial sequence information covering both inter- and intraspecific variability is available for Achnanthidium on GenBank. This is crucial for the success of automated molecular species delimitation methods, as these methods rely on sufficient sampling of intraspecific variation in at least some taxa included in the analyses. Furthermore, molecular phylogenies have previously been used in combination with morphology to delimit species within Achnanthidium, ensuring that species-boundaries in this genus are relatively well understood (e.g., Pinseel et al., 2017; Miao et al., 2020). A priori knowledge of species boundaries ensures that the output of the automated species delimitation methods can be evaluated against expected outcomes. In our case, where we use a short rbcL barcode as marker, this is a crucial advantage when evaluating the resolution of these methods which typically make use of longer sequences of highly variable genes (e.g., Pinseel et al., 2020). Unfortunately, the other four genera have little sequence information attached to them and molecular species boundaries have barely been studied at best, rendering them unsuitable for the analysis performed here.

Prior to running ABGD and SPNA, we downloaded all available rbcL sequences of the genera Achnanthidium and Psammothidium. Psammothidium was included because phylogenetic analyses have shown that Psammothidium clusters within Achnanthidium (Nakov, 2014). We aligned GenBank sequences and ASVs using CLUSTAL-W in BioEdit v7.2.5 (Hall, 1999), resulting in a maximum of 1379 aligned positions (i.e., longest sequence in the alignment). The alignment included two outgroup sequences, i.e., Placoneis elginensis and Adlafia brockmannii, following (Nakov et al., 2018). Subsequently, identical sequences 
were identified and removed so that the final alignments contained only unique haplotypes. This resulted in 87 aligned sequences (ASVs and outgroup included) which were used as input for SPNA and ABGD.

SPNA was performed in TCS1.21 (Clement et al., 2000), using a 99 % threshold as connection limit and with missing positions at the head and tails of the sequences treated as missing data. ABGD was performed on the online webserver (https://bioinfo.mnhn.fr/abi/public/abgd/abgdweb.html) with default settings, apart from the distance model, which was set to K80, the number of steps, which was adjusted to 100, and the X-value which was adjusted to 0.5. We selected the third initial partition, which was the most stable across all partitions. Outgroup sequences were removed prior to running SPNA and ABGD.

To visualize the taxa delimited by the automated molecular species delimitation methods in a phylogenetic framework, we generated a ML phylogeny using RAxML version 8.2.11 (Stamatakis, 2014). Prior to running RAxML, we obtained the best-fit substitution model by using the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) in jModelTest version 2.1.10 (Darriba et al., 2012) as implemented on the CIPRES Science Gateway (Miller et al., 2010). RAxML was run using 10 independent runs and 1000 pseudoreplicates under a GTR + G + I substitution model. ASVs were not included in this analysis. Next, ASVs were placed in the ML tree with RAxML-EPA version 0.3.5 (Berger et al., 2011), using a GTR + G + F model. At last, putative species delimited by the automated molecular species delimitation methods were visualized in the haplotype network obtained in the previous section.

2 METHOD
2.1 Study site and sampling
Lake Geneva is 73 km long and 14 km wide. Its maximum depth is 310 m, it has a surface area of 582 km2 and a volume of 89 km3. The mean retention time of the water is 11 years. It is a monomictic meso-oligotrophic lake. This lake receives water mainly from 18 rivers (positions of their inlets are shown in Figure 1), some being alpine rivers (east side of the lake) and some being hill rivers (west side of the lake).

Details are in the caption following the image
FIGURE 1
Open in figure viewer
PowerPoint
Location of the sampling sites and lake tributaries. Benthic diatoms were sampled on stones at 40–80 cm depth in June 2017
We sampled littoral diatoms in 153 sites from June 14 to 27, 2017 (Figure 1) following European standards for sampling diatoms in lakes (CEN, 2014) and for subsequent metabarcoding analyses (CEN, 2018b). The dominant substrate was stones. Therefore, five stones were collected at 40–60 cm water depth at each site. Their upper surface was scraped using a toothbrush. The biofilms were collected and fixed with 96% ethanol to a final concentration of >70%. Then samples were kept at 4°C in the dark until DNA extractions were carried out 1 month later. Among these 153 sites, we considered three types of sampling sites: (i) 20 river sites located within the river's estuary where river flow is visible, among which seven corresponded to alpine rivers and 13 to hill rivers; (ii) 34 estuarine sites located <50 m from the river estuary; and (iii) 99 lake sites located more than 50 m away from river estuaries. The threshold of 50 m was defined based on a previous study, which showed that river impact on diatom communities in Lake Geneva was very limited beyond this distance (Rimet et al., 2016). Indeed, the influence of river water has a limited impact of a few tens of square metres because the river water is denser than the lake water and quickly sinks to deep layers of the lake.

Finally, four plankton samples were taken in the middle of the lake, in the framework of the lake monitoring, close to the benthic sampling dates (May 15, June 1 and 21, July 4). Samplings were carried out between 0 and 20 m depth following a standardized methodology (Rimet et al., 2020).

Chemical and physical parameters were measured in the field (pH, O2, temperature, conductivity, turbidity, chlorophyll a) using field probes (Orion 5 Stars probe, multiparameter probe SST - CTM214) and in the laboratory using standard procedures (APHA, 1995: alkalinity, NH4+, NO2−, NO3−, total N, PO43−, total P, TOC [total organic carbon], Ca2+, K+, Mg2+, Na+, Cl−, SO42−, total suspended matter, organic suspended matter and SiO2).

2.2 DNA extraction and sequencing
DNA extractions and PCR (polymerase chain reaction) were carried out as described in Rivera et al. (2020). Suspended diatom biofilm (2 ml) was centrifuged for 30 min at 8000 g. A commercial DNA extraction kit (Macheray-Nagel NucleoSpin Soil kit, MN-Soil) was used following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quantity and quality were checked spectrophotometrically (NanoDrop 1000 Spectrophotometer, Thermo Fisher Scientific). We amplified a 312-bp barcode of chloroplastic DNA, which is embedded in the rbcL gene (coding for ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase). This barcode is recommended for diatom species identification (e.g., Kermarrec et al., 2013; Pissaridou et al., 2021; Vasselon, Domaizon, et al., 2017). We used diatom-specific primers given in Vasselon, Rimet, et al. (2017): Diat_rbcL_708F_1 (AGGTGAAGTAAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA), Diat_rbcL_708F_2 (AGGTGAAGTTAAAGGTTCWTAYTTAAA) and Diat_rbcL_708F_3 (AGGTGAAACTAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA) as forward, and Diat_rbcL_R3_1 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACWACTG) and Diat_rbcL_R3_2 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACAACAG) as reverse. Each DNA extract was amplified in triplicate using equimolar mixes of the three forward and two reverse primers. Half of the P5 (CTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT) and P7 (GGAGTTCAGACGTGTGCTCTTCCGATCT) Illumina adapters were included with the 5′ part of the rbcL forward and reverse primers, respectively. Additionally, blank samples using water for molecular processing were run in parallel to check for potential contaminations. Amplifications were performed in a final volume of 25 μl following mix and reaction conditions used previously, the number of amplifications was set to 33 and the conditions of a cycle were as follows: 95°C for 1 min, 54°C for 1 min and 72°C for 1 min (Rivera et al., 2020). The three replicates prepared for each DNA sample were pooled. From this pool, 50 μl was sent to the sequencing company ID Gene in the framework of a France–Switzerland project (Lefrançois et al., 2018). The PCR amplicons were purified and used as templates in a second PCR that used Illumina tailed primers targeting one half of the P5 and P7 sequences. Finally, all generated PCR amplicons were dual-indexed and pooled into a single tube as presented by Apothéloz-Perret-Gentil et al. (2021). The final pool was sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq platform using the V2 paired-end sequencing kit (2 × 250 bp).

A total of 9,746,186 reads were obtained from a single run of good quality (see Figures S1 and S2), comparable to numbers of reads obtained in previous studies (e.g., Rivera et al., 2020).

2.3 Bioinformatic analysis
The dada2 pipeline (Callahan et al., 2016) was used for the bioinformatics treatment of the demultiplexed MiSeq reads. A pipeline adapted to diatom metabarcoding sequence data (available on https://github.com/fkeck/DADA2_diatoms_pipeline) and previously described (Tapolczai et al., 2021) was applied. In brief, primer removal from R1 and R2 reads was carried out with cutadapt 2.9 (Martin, 2011). The quality profiles of R1 and R2 reads were checked and the pattern showed good read quality and only the last 20–30 bp decreased in the quality score (Figure S1).

R1 and R2 reads were filtered and truncated to remove poor quality sequences (truncLen = c(200, 170), maxN = 0, maxEE = c(2, 2), truncQ = 2). Estimated error rates fit well to the observed rates and the error rates decrease with increased quality (Figure S2). Sequences were dereplicated, ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) were inferred and chimeras were removed. Read numbers in each sample were tracked after each bioinformatic step (Table S3). The taxonomic assignment of ASVs was carried out with an open-access adapted version (9) (https://www6.inrae.fr/carrtel-collection/Barcoding-database/) of the Diat.barcode reference barcoding library (Rimet, Feret, et al., 2019; Rimet, Gusev, et al., 2019). This library follows European standards for reference barcoding library management (CEN, 2018a; Rimet et al., 2021). We used the R package “diat.barcode” (Keck, 2020), with a minimum bootstrap confidence of 60 (according to Rivera et al., 2020) for assigning a taxon at the most resolved taxonomic level (Table S4). After applying quality filters, merging and removing chimeras, 8,014,802 reads remained.

ASVs that were not assigned to diatoms were removed from the subsequent analyses, leaving 7,496,144 reads distributed in 755 ASVs. To check for PCR sequencing errors, the ASVs were aligned and compared to the reference alignment available in the reference barcoding library Diat.barcode (Rimet, Feret, et al., 2019; Rimet, Gusev, et al., 2019): no indels were detected. Moreover, no stop-codons were present (translation carried out in mega10, Kumar et al., 2018).

Read numbers of ASVs per sample were transformed into relative abundances of ASVs per sample (number of reads of an ASV in a sample/number of reads in a sample). The average read number in a sample was 48,994 (min: 7323, max: 73,749). When considering the 10 most abundant species, the number of ASVs ranged from five to 23 per species, with an average of 12.

All data (Fastq, datatables) are available at doi: 10.15454/MYHBSI (Rimet, 2021).

2.4 Data analysis
2.4.1 Analysis of the community phylogenetic structure
NRI and NTI metrics measure whether the community is phylogenetically over-dispersed or clustered and some authors have interpreted these as proxies of environmental filtering or competitive exclusion, respectively (Webb, 2000). NRI measures whether the genetic distances between each pair of individuals in a community are greater or smaller than those expected from a randomly generated community. A positive NRI value indicates that the community is phylogenetically clustered, and that environmental filtering dominates. A negative NRI value indicates the community is phylogenetically over-dispersed and therefore competitive exclusion dominates. NTI measures if the most phylogenetically close taxa in a community co-occur more or less than expected in a random community, and has the same interpretation as NRI.

To calculate NRI and NTI, we did not use phylogenetic distances measured solely between ASVs because ASVs are only 263 bp. With such a short amplicon, the phylogenetic distance is underestimated when considering species that are phylogenetically distant from each other. To avoid this bias, ASVs were introduced in a phylogeny built with the entire rbcL gene. Then, we extracted the distances between the ASVs from this phylogeny. Briefly, the phylogenetic metrics NRI and NTI were calculated following these three steps:

Phylogeny of diatoms and ASV placements
A global alignment of rbcL sequences is available in Diat.barcode version 9 (Rimet, Feret, et al., 2019; Rimet, Gusev, et al., 2019). Long sequences (total: 3253 sequences) were extracted from it, and the best substitution model was then tested in mega 10.1 (Kumar et al., 2016). A maximum-likelihood phylogeny was calculated following the best substitution model (100 rapid bootstraps—GTRGAMMA) with raxmlGUI (Silvestro & Michalak, 2012), and calculation lasted 46 hr with an Intel Core i5-8250U CPU @ 1.60 GHz. Then, the short sequences of the Diat.barcode (1464 sequences) and the 300 most abundant ASVs were placed onto this phylogeny using the option “Use multifurcating constraint.” This option allows us to add sequences using the topology of the phylogeny previously calculated using the EPA—Evolutionary Placement Algorithm (Berger et al., 2011)—included in raxmlGUI. We only placed the 300 most frequent ASVs (out of 755 ASVs) because of the computation time of the phylogeny (31 hr of calculation). These 300 ASVs also represent 99% of the reads of the run (the other ASVs were rare). A phylogenetic tree showing the position of ASVs was drawn with the phylosignal R package (Keck, Rimet, Bouchez, & Franc, 2016) and is given in Data S9. Phylogenetic distances between ASVs were extracted from the tree with the function cophenetic of the “stats” R package.

OTU generation from ASVs at 99%–85% sequence similarity
OTUs were generated from the 300 aligned ASVs using the function seq_cluster of the “bioseq” R package (https://fkeck.github.io/bioseq/index.html) using the Farthest Neighbour Clustering option and identity thresholds ranging from 99% to 85%. In general, 97% and 95% similarity are used as a proxy for diatom species (Evans et al., 2007), and 85% corresponds to the family level. For each OTU, we considered the most abundant one as the representative ASV.

Calculation of NRI and NTI indices
To calculate the NRI and NTI indices, the functions ses.mpd and ses.mntd of the “picante” R package (Kembel et al., 2010) were used and their results were multiplied by −1 to transform the results into NRI and NTI indices. Distances from the raxmlGUI tree were used, and the NRI and NTI indices were calculated for each of the diatom communities of the 153 samples. NRI and NTI indices were calculated for the communities expressed in ASV percentages.

NTI was developed to detect patterns near the tips, so its use is not recommended for higher taxonomic levels. Therefore, NTI was used only on ASVs while NRI was used for OTUs (from 99% to 85% sequence similarity).

2.4.2 Analysis of environmental and spatial effects
To complement the phylogenetic analysis, we also used a variation partitioning approach to assess the relative importance of environmental filtering (chemical parameters) and spatial parameters on diatom communities. Variance partitioning was based on a redundancy analysis (RDA) and was carried out using the function varpart of the “Vegan” R package (Oksanen et al., 2013). Chemical parameters were centred-reduced. For spatial parameters, sampling site coordinates were transformed following the PCNM (principal coordinates of neighbour matrices) method (Borcard et al., 2004) using the same procedure given in Rimet, Feret, et al. (2019). For each kind of data—standardized chemical data and spatial parameters—a forward selection was carried out to select the significant parameters. To this end, we used the “ordistep” function in the ‘Vegan’ R package.

Variance partitioning was calculated separately for estuarine sites and lakes sites.

2.4.3 Analysis of the mass effect
We defined three types of source communities. Benthic diatom communities in the lake biofilms can come from rivers inlets (see river inlets in Figure 1) or sediment from the plankton. Two types of rivers flow into Lake Geneva, with different diatom communities (Tison et al., 2005): alpine rivers (mostly from the east part of the lake) and hill rivers (mostly from the west part of the lake). The 20 river estuaries samples were considered as two different sources: the first source was communities from the seven alpine rivers, while the second source was communities from the 13 hill rivers. Finally, the third source was communities from the four plankton samples.

We defined two sink communities: those from estuarine sites and those from lakes.

Data S5 lists the samples considered as the source or sink environments.

To visualize the differences between the three source communities and the two sink communities, a nonmetric dimensional scaling (NMDS) was calculated based on the species composition (Bray–Curtis distances). To test if these communities were significantly different, a PERMANOVA was used. Then, to identify the typical species of the source and sink communities we conducted a SIMPER analysis. These three analyses were carried out on the species composition of the samples, and past freeware (version 4.01, Hammer et al., 2001) was used for the calculations.

SourceTracker analysis (Knights et al., 2011), a Bayesian based method, was used to quantify the extent to which river communities contribute to lake communities through the mass effect. This method has been successfully applied in natural aquatic environments (Comte et al., 2017; Henry et al., 2016). To this end, we used the source and sink communities defined above.
column5:
2.1 Study site and sampling
Lake Geneva is 73 km long and 14 km wide. Its maximum depth is 310 m, it has a surface area of 582 km2 and a volume of 89 km3. The mean retention time of the water is 11 years. It is a monomictic meso-oligotrophic lake. This lake receives water mainly from 18 rivers (positions of their inlets are shown in Figure 1), some being alpine rivers (east side of the lake) and some being hill rivers (west side of the lake).

Details are in the caption following the image
FIGURE 1
Open in figure viewer
PowerPoint
Location of the sampling sites and lake tributaries. Benthic diatoms were sampled on stones at 40–80 cm depth in June 2017
We sampled littoral diatoms in 153 sites from June 14 to 27, 2017 (Figure 1) following European standards for sampling diatoms in lakes (CEN, 2014) and for subsequent metabarcoding analyses (CEN, 2018b). The dominant substrate was stones. Therefore, five stones were collected at 40–60 cm water depth at each site. Their upper surface was scraped using a toothbrush. The biofilms were collected and fixed with 96% ethanol to a final concentration of >70%. Then samples were kept at 4°C in the dark until DNA extractions were carried out 1 month later. Among these 153 sites, we considered three types of sampling sites: (i) 20 river sites located within the river's estuary where river flow is visible, among which seven corresponded to alpine rivers and 13 to hill rivers; (ii) 34 estuarine sites located <50 m from the river estuary; and (iii) 99 lake sites located more than 50 m away from river estuaries. The threshold of 50 m was defined based on a previous study, which showed that river impact on diatom communities in Lake Geneva was very limited beyond this distance (Rimet et al., 2016). Indeed, the influence of river water has a limited impact of a few tens of square metres because the river water is denser than the lake water and quickly sinks to deep layers of the lake.

Finally, four plankton samples were taken in the middle of the lake, in the framework of the lake monitoring, close to the benthic sampling dates (May 15, June 1 and 21, July 4). Samplings were carried out between 0 and 20 m depth following a standardized methodology (Rimet et al., 2020).

Chemical and physical parameters were measured in the field (pH, O2, temperature, conductivity, turbidity, chlorophyll a) using field probes (Orion 5 Stars probe, multiparameter probe SST - CTM214) and in the laboratory using standard procedures (APHA, 1995: alkalinity, NH4+, NO2−, NO3−, total N, PO43−, total P, TOC [total organic carbon], Ca2+, K+, Mg2+, Na+, Cl−, SO42−, total suspended matter, organic suspended matter and SiO2).
column6: DNA extractions and PCR (polymerase chain reaction) were carried out as described in Rivera et al. (2020). Suspended diatom biofilm (2 ml) was centrifuged for 30 min at 8000 g. A commercial DNA extraction kit (Macheray-Nagel NucleoSpin Soil kit, MN-Soil) was used following the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quantity and quality were checked spectrophotometrically (NanoDrop 1000 Spectrophotometer, Thermo Fisher Scientific).
column8:
We amplified a 312-bp barcode of chloroplastic DNA, which is embedded in the rbcL gene (coding for ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase). This barcode is recommended for diatom species identification (e.g., Kermarrec et al., 2013; Pissaridou et al., 2021; Vasselon, Domaizon, et al., 2017). We used diatom-specific primers given in Vasselon, Rimet, et al. (2017): Diat_rbcL_708F_1 (AGGTGAAGTAAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA), Diat_rbcL_708F_2 (AGGTGAAGTTAAAGGTTCWTAYTTAAA) and Diat_rbcL_708F_3 (AGGTGAAACTAAAGGTTCWTACTTAAA) as forward, and Diat_rbcL_R3_1 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACWACTG) and Diat_rbcL_R3_2 (CCTTCTAATTTACCWACAACAG) as reverse. Each DNA extract was amplified in triplicate using equimolar mixes of the three forward and two reverse primers. Half of the P5 (CTTTCCCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT) and P7 (GGAGTTCAGACGTGTGCTCTTCCGATCT) Illumina adapters were included with the 5′ part of the rbcL forward and reverse primers, respectively. Additionally, blank samples using water for molecular processing were run in parallel to check for potential contaminations. Amplifications were performed in a final volume of 25 μl following mix and reaction conditions used previously, the number of amplifications was set to 33 and the conditions of a cycle were as follows: 95°C for 1 min, 54°C for 1 min and 72°C for 1 min (Rivera et al., 2020). The three replicates prepared for each DNA sample were pooled. From this pool, 50 μl was sent to the sequencing company ID Gene in the framework of a France–Switzerland project (Lefrançois et al., 2018). The PCR amplicons were purified and used as templates in a second PCR that used Illumina tailed primers targeting one half of the P5 and P7 sequences. Finally, all generated PCR amplicons were dual-indexed and pooled into a single tube as presented by Apothéloz-Perret-Gentil et al. (2021). The final pool was sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq platform using the V2 paired-end sequencing kit (2 × 250 bp).

A total of 9,746,186 reads were obtained from a single run of good quality (see Figures S1 and S2), comparable to numbers of reads obtained in previous studies (e.g., Rivera et al., 2020).
